headline: OPEC to Meet Amid Signs of Waning Influence on Oil Prices
abstract: Major producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are set to gather virtually on Sunday. They are expected to maintain production cuts amid signs of a softening market.
snippet: Major producers, including Saudi Arabia and Russia, are set to gather virtually on Sunday. They are expected to maintain production cuts amid signs of a softening market.
lead_paragraph: When officials from many of the world’s biggest oil-producing countries meet on Sunday, their menu of options for managing the market may be limited.

headline: Another Big Oil Deal Despite Regulatory Pushback and Market Volatility
abstract: ConocoPhillips has agreed to buy Marathon Oil for $22.5 billion, as consolidation in the U.S. energy sector shows little sign of slowing down.
snippet: ConocoPhillips has agreed to buy Marathon Oil for $22.5 billion, as consolidation in the U.S. energy sector shows little sign of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: Bullish predictions for $100 crude oil may not have come to fruition, but that hasn’t stopped the deal frenzy in the fossil fuel sector.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Edmund Lee

headline: ConocoPhillips to Acquire Marathon Oil in $22.5 Billion Deal
abstract: The takeover is the latest in a wave of consolidation sweeping the oil industry, with the biggest players rushing to acquire smaller rivals.
snippet: The takeover is the latest in a wave of consolidation sweeping the oil industry, with the biggest players rushing to acquire smaller rivals.
lead_paragraph: ConocoPhillips agreed on Wednesday to acquire its smaller rival, Marathon Oil, the latest deal in a wave of consolidation sweeping the oil industry. The burst of mergers and acquisitions has tracked a robust recovery in commodity prices, with the major players emboldened by record profits and high share prices.
byline: By Bernhard Warner and Rebecca F. Elliott

headline: Saudi Arabia Eyes a Future Beyond Oil
abstract: The kingdom is trying to juggle its still-vital petroleum industry with alternative energy sources like wind and solar as it faces pressure to lower carbon emissions.
snippet: The kingdom is trying to juggle its still-vital petroleum industry with alternative energy sources like wind and solar as it faces pressure to lower carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: At a two-hour drive from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia’s capital, rows of solar panels extend to the horizon like waves on an ocean. Despite having almost limitless reserves of oil, the kingdom is embracing solar and wind power, partly in an effort to retain a leading position in the energy industry, which is vitally important to the country but fast changing.

headline: Chevron’s $53 Billion Oil Deal Is Backed by Hess Shareholders
abstract: Hurdles remain as Chevron and Exxon Mobil wage a legal battle over Hess’s stake in a lucrative oil project in Guyana.
snippet: Hurdles remain as Chevron and Exxon Mobil wage a legal battle over Hess’s stake in a lucrative oil project in Guyana.
lead_paragraph: A large oil industry deal advanced on Tuesday after shareholders of Hess approved a proposed sale of the company to Chevron for $53 billion.

headline: Can Trump Really Slam the Brakes on Electric Vehicles?
abstract: He has vowed to shred President Biden’s E.V. policies and has threatened that “You won’t be able to sell those cars.”
snippet: He has vowed to shred President Biden’s E.V. policies and has threatened that “You won’t be able to sell those cars.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is crystal clear about his disdain for electric vehicles. The former president has falsely claimed electric cars don’t work, promised to shred President Biden’s policies that encourage E.V. manufacturing and sales, and has said he would slap a “100 percent tariff” on electric cars imported from Mexico if he retakes the White House.
byline: By Coral Davenport and Jack Ewing

headline: Biden Doesn’t Want You Buying an E.V. From China. Here’s Why.
abstract: The president wants to shift America’s car fleet toward electric vehicles, but not at the expense of American jobs or national security.
snippet: The president wants to shift America’s car fleet toward electric vehicles, but not at the expense of American jobs or national security.
lead_paragraph: President Biden wants more of America’s cars and trucks to run on electricity, not gas. His administration has pushed that goal on multiple fronts, including strict new regulations of auto emissions and lavish new subsidies to help American consumers take as much as $7,500 off the cost of a new electric vehicle.

headline: How ‘Furiosa’ Fits Into the ‘Mad Max’ Timeline
abstract: “Furiosa” is a prequel that intersects with the earlier movies in surprising ways. Here’s a chronology, plus our ideal order for watching the whole series.
snippet: “Furiosa” is a prequel that intersects with the earlier movies in surprising ways. Here’s a chronology, plus our ideal order for watching the whole series.
lead_paragraph: “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga” is roaring into theaters, widely advertised as a prequel to the director George Miller’s 2015 hit, “Mad Max: Fury Road.” But that was the fourth film in a series that, until now, was chronological, so where does “Furiosa” fit in? How else do these movies intersect, with the numerous cast changes and recalibrations in the 45 years since the inaugural entry? Whether you’re approaching the franchise as a novice or looking for a quick refresher, here’s how it all fits together:

headline: These Teens Adopted an Orphaned Oil Well. Their Goal: Shut It Down.
abstract: Students, nonprofit groups and others are fund-raising to cap highly polluting oil and gas wells abandoned by industry.
snippet: Students, nonprofit groups and others are fund-raising to cap highly polluting oil and gas wells abandoned by industry.
lead_paragraph: As a child in Bolivia, Mateo De La Rocha told his family he wanted to work as a garbage man when he grew up. In La Paz, his home city at the time, trash piles were everywhere. In Mr. De La Rocha’s eyes, the local sanitation worker was the only person cleaning up pollution. “I didn’t really see anyone doing anything about it, apart from the garbage man,” he said.

headline: Senate Democrats Open Inquiry Into Trump’s $1 Billion Request of Oil Industry
abstract: Two committees are seeking information from oil executives about a dinner where, the lawmakers say, the former president proposed a quid pro quo.
snippet: Two committees are seeking information from oil executives about a dinner where, the lawmakers say, the former president proposed a quid pro quo.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats opened an investigation on Thursday into former President Donald J. Trump’s meeting with oil and gas executives last month to determine whether Mr. Trump offered a “policies-for-money transaction” when he asked for $1 billion for his 2024 campaign so he could retake the White House and delete President Biden’s climate regulations.

headline: A Giant Crater in Siberia Is Belching Up Russia’s Past
abstract: A yawning hole in the Siberian landscape should be a warning about the dangers of extraction.
snippet: A yawning hole in the Siberian landscape should be a warning about the dangers of extraction.
lead_paragraph: As the world warms, permafrost is thawing across two-thirds of Russia, threatening cities and towns that were constructed to house miners sent to dig up a subterranean trove of oil, gas, gold and diamonds. Even the roads are buckling, cracking and collapsing, as if in a slow-motion earthquake. And outside a small town called Batagay, deep in the Siberian hinterland, a crater is rapidly opening up — known to local residents as the gateway to the underworld.

headline: Testing the Nvidia Boom
abstract: Expectations are sky-high for the chipmaker’s latest earnings report. The company is at the center of Wall Street’s focus on artificial intelligence.
snippet: Expectations are sky-high for the chipmaker’s latest earnings report. The company is at the center of Wall Street’s focus on artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Despite concerns about stubbornly high inflation, elevated interest rates and ballooning U.S. debt, the S&P 500 is trading at a record on Wednesday, having soared 27 percent over the past year.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

headline: Biden Administration Will Release 1 Million Barrels of Gasoline
abstract: The sale, which was mandated by Congress, is timed to the summer driving season but unlikely to have more than a modest effect on gasoline prices.
snippet: The sale, which was mandated by Congress, is timed to the summer driving season but unlikely to have more than a modest effect on gasoline prices.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it would sell off one million barrels of gasoline over the coming weeks from a strategic reserve in the Northeast, a move it said was designed to keep gasoline prices in check for consumers ahead of the July 4 holiday.

headline: Return of the Inflation Truthers
abstract: Cutting through the misconceptions and conspiracy theories.
snippet: Cutting through the misconceptions and conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: Has U.S. inflation come down? Yes. We have two main measures of inflation: the Consumer Price Index, which pretty much everyone knows about, and the Personal Consumption Expenditures index, which the Federal Reserve prefers as a guide to monetary policy; explaining the differences between these measures would probably be telling you more than you want to know. Anyway, the P.C.E. is currently looking more benign than the C.P.I., but both show that the rate of price increases over the past year was much slower than it was when inflation was at its peak in 2022:

headline: Biden and Big Oil Had a Truce. Now, It’s Collapsing.
abstract: Companies were enjoying record profits. But the president’s decision to pause permits for gas export terminals has whipped up industry support, and donations, for Donald Trump.
snippet: Companies were enjoying record profits. But the president’s decision to pause permits for gas export terminals has whipped up industry support, and donations, for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Early in his term, President Biden seemed to have struck an uneasy truce with the oil and gas industry.
byline: By Lisa Friedman and Rebecca F. Elliott

headline: Israel and Gaza: Despair and What-Ifs
abstract: Readers disagree about a guest essay by Megan K. Stack. Also: Big politics in politics; “journey” as metaphor; helping the mentally ill and homeless.
snippet: Readers disagree about a guest essay by Megan K. Stack. Also: Big politics in politics; “journey” as metaphor; helping the mentally ill and homeless.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Russia’s War Machine Revs Up as the West’s Plan to Cap Oil Revenues Sputters
abstract: Russia has largely evaded attempts by the U.S. and Europe to keep it from profiting from its energy exports.
snippet: Russia has largely evaded attempts by the U.S. and Europe to keep it from profiting from its energy exports.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies in the Group of 7 nations set two goals in 2022 when they enacted a novel plan to cap the price of Russian oil: restrict Moscow’s ability to profit from its energy exports while allowing its oil to continue flowing on international markets to prevent a global price shock.

headline: Russia and Ukraine Engage in Dueling Air Assaults Behind the Front Lines
abstract: Both sides have been looking for ways to inflict damage beyond the battlefield, targeting military logistics hubs and urban centers.
snippet: Both sides have been looking for ways to inflict damage beyond the battlefield, targeting military logistics hubs and urban centers.
lead_paragraph: Russia and Ukraine targeted each other’s territory on Sunday with drone attacks and airstrikes that hit urban centers and energy facilities, as both sides look for ways to inflict damage beyond the battlefield.

headline: Israel Resists Grand Bargain as U.S. and Saudis Work on Security Pact
abstract: President Biden is pushing for a broad deal that would get Israel to approve a Palestinian state in return for Saudi recognition of Israel. But officials need to overcome Israeli opposition.
snippet: President Biden is pushing for a broad deal that would get Israel to approve a Palestinian state in return for Saudi recognition of Israel. But officials need to overcome Israeli opposition.
lead_paragraph: Two years into President Biden’s term, his aides began negotiating with Saudi leaders to have the kingdom establish diplomatic relations with Israel. But when the Israel-Hamas war began last October, the talks withered.
byline: By Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim

headline: Gov. Gavin Newsom Accuses Trump of ‘Open Corruption’ at Climate Meeting
abstract: The California governor, speaking at the Vatican, used sharp language to describe the former president’s appeal to fossil fuel executives for campaign donations.
snippet: The California governor, speaking at the Vatican, used sharp language to describe the former president’s appeal to fossil fuel executives for campaign donations.
lead_paragraph: Burnishing his climate credentials at a conference hosted by Pope Francis at the Vatican on Thursday, California’s governor, Gavin Newsom, criticized former President Donald J. Trump for reportedly meeting with fossil fuel executives and asking them for $1 billion in contributions to his election campaign.

headline: What’s at Stake in Venezuela’s Presidential Election
abstract: A fair and credible vote, restoring democracy and reuniting families separated by migration are all top of mind as voters go to the polls on Sunday.
snippet: A fair and credible vote, restoring democracy and reuniting families separated by migration are all top of mind as voters go to the polls on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s authoritarian president, will soon confront his toughest electoral challenge since taking office in 2013.

headline: Barge Hits Bridge in Galveston, Texas
abstract: The vessel struck the Pelican Island Bridge, spilling oil into Galveston Bay.
snippet: The vessel struck the Pelican Island Bridge, spilling oil into Galveston Bay.
lead_paragraph: The vessel struck the Pelican Island Bridge, spilling oil into Galveston Bay.

headline: How China Rose to Lead the World in Cars and Solar Panels
abstract: Heavy subsidies for industry, together with weak sales in China, have set the stage for an export boom, raising fears of factory job losses elsewhere.
snippet: Heavy subsidies for industry, together with weak sales in China, have set the stage for an export boom, raising fears of factory job losses elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: For decades, China has moved methodically to dominate ever more industries, from toys and clothing in the 1980s to semiconductors and renewable energy today. China now produces a third of the world’s manufactured goods — more than the United States, Germany, Japan, South Korea and Britain combined. Its trade surplus in these goods is equal to a tenth of the entire Chinese economy.

headline: 1907 Was a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
abstract: In “The Race to the Future,” Kassia St. Clair chronicles the 8,000-mile caper that helped change the landscape forever.
snippet: In “The Race to the Future,” Kassia St. Clair chronicles the 8,000-mile caper that helped change the landscape forever.
lead_paragraph: Berkeley Heights, N.J., was once a verdant expanse of farmland and forests, but by the time I grew up there, all that had long been paved over to build suburban homes. So I spent most of my time inside, watching movies on TV.

headline: Want to Fix Social Security? The Well-Off Must Accept Smaller Checks.
abstract: Voters won’t brook much higher taxes, so Social Security needs to be reoriented toward the poor.
snippet: Voters won’t brook much higher taxes, so Social Security needs to be reoriented toward the poor.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years. That’s all that’s left until the combined Social Security accounts — the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Disability Insurance Trust Fund — are likely to run out of money and can no longer pay full scheduled benefits, according to the latest report of the Social Security trustees.

headline: We Can Get the Electricity We Need Without Frying the Planet (or Our Pocketbooks)
abstract: We need utilities to succeed now more than ever before. But the definition of success needs to evolve.
snippet: We need utilities to succeed now more than ever before. But the definition of success needs to evolve.
lead_paragraph: Electric utilities from Georgia to Wisconsin to Virginia are predicting a dizzying surge in power demand from new industrial facilities, electric vehicles and, most of all, the data centers that store our digital photos and will enable large-language models for artificial intelligence. For months now, they have been signaling that they won’t be able to keep up.

headline: Women at Work, and With Their Families Too
abstract: Readers respond to a guest essay about mothers and careers. Also: Mythologizing Donald Trump; a mental health tragedy; offshore drilling.
snippet: Readers respond to a guest essay about mothers and careers. Also: Mythologizing Donald Trump; a mental health tragedy; offshore drilling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
snippet: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: As a rift between two longstanding allies widens, Israeli leaders said that they would not be deterred by President Biden’s threat to withhold arms shipments if the military launched a full-scale invasion of Rafah, where about a million Palestinians are sheltering. An Israeli military spokesman said his nation had enough munitions on hand to proceed with its plans.

headline: Donald Trump’s Lawyer Pressed Stormy Daniels
abstract: Also, a setback in Gaza cease-fire talks. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
snippet: Also, a setback in Gaza cease-fire talks. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer representing Donald Trump in his criminal trial in Manhattan spent more than two hours today attempting to undermine the credibility of one of the prosecution’s most high-profile witnesses.

headline: Friday Briefing: Stormy Daniels, Day Two
abstract: Also, Israel-Hamas talks falter again.
snippet: Also, Israel-Hamas talks falter again.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Donald Trump again sought to make Stormy Daniels look as if she was lying yesterday about her account of a 2006 sexual liaison. But Daniels — who took the $130,000 hush-money payment at the heart of the 34 felony charges Trump is facing — pushed back.

headline: Ukraine Strikes More Russian Oil Facilities in a Bid to Disrupt Military Logistics
abstract: Analysts say Ukraine is trying to disrupt the Russian military’s logistical routes and combat operations by targeting the facilities that supply fuel for its tanks, ships and fighter jets.
snippet: Analysts say Ukraine is trying to disrupt the Russian military’s logistical routes and combat operations by targeting the facilities that supply fuel for its tanks, ships and fighter jets.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian drones struck two oil depots and a refinery across Russia in a 24-hour period, including one deep in Russian territory, officials on both sides said Thursday, as Kyiv presses a campaign aimed at hampering the country’s military operations and putting strain on its most important industry.

headline: At a Dinner, Trump Assailed Climate Rules and Asked $1 Billion From Big Oil
abstract: At a private meeting at Mar-a-Lago, the former president said fossil fuel companies should donate to help him beat President Biden.
snippet: At a private meeting at Mar-a-Lago, the former president said fossil fuel companies should donate to help him beat President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump told a group of oil executives and lobbyists gathered at a dinner at his Mar-a-Lago resort last month that they should donate $1 billion to his presidential campaign because, if elected, he would roll back environmental rules that he said hampered their industry, according to two people who were there.
byline: By Lisa Friedman, Coral Davenport, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

headline: Elite Colleges Walked Into the Israel Divestment Trap
abstract: Colleges cannot accede to student protesters’ demands that they jettison investments because of the war in Gaza.
snippet: Colleges cannot accede to student protesters’ demands that they jettison investments because of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: “Disclose, divest, we will not stop, we will not rest” is a frequent chant ringing through pro-Palestinian college protests. Of all the actions one could advocate in the war between Israel and Hamas, protesters at Columbia listed, as their first demand, that it divest from companies and institutions that, in their view, “profit from Israeli apartheid.”

headline: 10 Big Biden Environmental Rules, and What They Mean
abstract: Asbestos, “forever” chemicals, E.V.s and endangered species. Here’s what 10 new rules cover, and why the administration has been churning them out.
snippet: Asbestos, “forever” chemicals, E.V.s and endangered species. Here’s what 10 new rules cover, and why the administration has been churning them out.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has been racing this spring to finalize a slew of major environmental regulations, including rules to combat climate change, a first-ever ban on asbestos and new limits on toxic chemicals in tap water.

headline: European Oil Giants Consider Shifting Their Listings to the U.S.
abstract: TotalEnergies and Shell are contemplating the advantages of listing shares in the United States to strengthen what they say are low market valuations.
snippet: TotalEnergies and Shell are contemplating the advantages of listing shares in the United States to strengthen what they say are low market valuations.
lead_paragraph: Two European energy giants, TotalEnergies of France and Shell of Britain, are considering moving their stock listings to New York, as pressure mounts for them to improve their valuations, which lag their American counterparts.

headline: Interstate 95 Reopens After Damaged Bridge Is Demolished
abstract: A section of the highway, a crucial link between Connecticut and New York City, had closed on Thursday when fuel from a burning tanker ignited an overpass.
snippet: A section of the highway, a crucial link between Connecticut and New York City, had closed on Thursday when fuel from a burning tanker ignited an overpass.
lead_paragraph: A section of Interstate 95 in Connecticut reopened on Sunday morning after a fiery accident last week damaged an overpass and shut down the highway, a major artery along the East Coast.

headline: Oil Companies Expand Offshore Drilling, Pointing to Energy Needs
abstract: Shell and others say they plan to drill for oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico in part because doing so releases fewer greenhouse gases than drilling on land.
snippet: Shell and others say they plan to drill for oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico in part because doing so releases fewer greenhouse gases than drilling on land.
lead_paragraph: About 80 miles southeast of Louisiana’s coast, 100,000 metric tons of steel floats in the Gulf of Mexico, an emblem of the hopes of oil and gas companies.

headline: The Peculiar Persistence of Trump-stalgia
abstract: Are you better off than you were four years ago? Yes.
snippet: Are you better off than you were four years ago? Yes.
lead_paragraph: “Are you better off than you were four years ago?” Lately, I’ve been seeing people repeat Ronald Reagan’s famous question, many of them apparently believing that they’re making a slam-dunk case for returning Donald Trump to power.

headline: Making Flying Cleaner
abstract: New guidelines attempt to make the aviation cleaner by relying on corn-based ethanol, but experts divided on the fuel’s environmental benefits.
snippet: New guidelines attempt to make the aviation cleaner by relying on corn-based ethanol, but experts divided on the fuel’s environmental benefits.
lead_paragraph: Flying is just about the most polluting thing many of us do.

headline: F.T.C. Clears Exxon Mobil’s Acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission will bar Pioneer’s chief executive, Scott Sheffield, from joining Exxon’s board, saying he colluded with OPEC to reduce oil production.
snippet: The Federal Trade Commission will bar Pioneer’s chief executive, Scott Sheffield, from joining Exxon’s board, saying he colluded with OPEC to reduce oil production.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday approved Exxon Mobil’s acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources as long as Exxon excludes Pioneer’s chief executive from its board.

headline: Bulgarian Distrust of Russia Simmers Over a Black Sea Oil Terminal
abstract: Russia has been losing its grip on the Rosenets Oil Terminal, near the port city of Burgas, as Bulgarian authorities seek to assert greater control over the Russian-run facility.
snippet: Russia has been losing its grip on the Rosenets Oil Terminal, near the port city of Burgas, as Bulgarian authorities seek to assert greater control over the Russian-run facility.
lead_paragraph: The oil terminal’s piers stretch just a few score yards into the Black Sea from the Bulgarian coast. For 25 years, the Russian crude they received fed a sprawling network of economic and political influence that helped keep Bulgaria tethered tightly to the Kremlin.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Hannah Ritchie
abstract: The April 30, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
snippet: The April 30, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Hannah Ritchie. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
